abstract.p: To make realistic maintenance decisions, it is important that maintenance managers make their preventive replacement decisions based on observations of the condition of their equipment. This study addresses a condition- and age-based replacement decision problem using the complete history of measured condition observations to minimize long-run average cost, maximize long-run average availability, or both. A stochastic filtering process (SFP) is used to estimate the residual lifetime distribution conditional on the history of observed condition information. A long-run average cost model and a long-run average availability model are analysed in order to determine the theorems necessary for calculating the optimum replacement time. To minimize the cost and maximize availability, a multiobjective decision frontier is proposed that will help maintenance managers deal with trade-offs between the two objectives. Finally, numerical examples are presented for each scenario to show the effectiveness of the methods proposed.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Preventive replacement is carried out to avoid higher failure replacement cost, resulting from production loss due to unplanned downtime and other logistic delays. Selecting an optimal replacement time is a crucial task for a maintenance manager. An age-based replacement policy is widely used [1–4] to determine optimum preventive replacement time. Sheu et al. [5] used an age-based replacement policy to derive expressions of long-run average cost for optimal replacement decision making. Further, researchers have been working to improve their determination of optimum replacement time through the incorporation of condition information [6–8].

For preventive replacement decisions, single or multiple objective functions may be used. The optimal replacement time, T*, is often determined either by minimizing the long-run average cost, C(T), or by maximizing the long-run average availability, A(T). The proportional hazard model (PHM) has been used to update the hazard function based on information regarding monitored condition information and equipment age [7]. Makis and Jardine [9] used the PHM to determine the risk level for equipment that minimizes the total cost per unit of time in replacement decision making. Li et al. [10] used the PHM to determine the remaining lifetime distribution. This remaining lifetime distribution was then used to find the replacement time that maximizes the long-run average availability. Scarf [11] used the PHM with an age-replacement model, in which the hazard rate was expressed as a function of condition information and age. Wang and Zhang [12] stated that the PHM used only the current observation, not the complete history of observed condition information.

There are other prognostic models available in the literature. For example, Camci [13] proposed a prognostic model for using information to predict the probability of failure and reliability to be expected after maintenance. A genetic algorithm is used to minimize risk, where risk is represented by the trade-off between failure and preventive maintenance. A stochastic filtering process (SFP) was used by Wang [6] to predict residual lifetime distribution considering the complete history of equipment condition. A graphical method was proposed for finding the replacement time, T*, which minimized the long-run average cost, C(T). Wang [14] combined the delay time concept, the hidden Markov model (HMM), and filtering theory to form a prognosis model for maintenance decision making. Lipi et al. [15] developed a preliminary model for age-based replacement decision making that considers the complete history condition information to maximize long-run average availability. They reported a preliminary relationship between the target level of availability and maintenance efficiency. This relationship assists maintenance managers in selecting maintenance crews capable of achieving a given target level of long-run average availability. Savsar [16] studied the effects of various maintenance policies on the production rate for ﬂexible manufacturing cells (FMCs). To analyse the effects of corrective, preventive, and opportunistic maintenance policies on the productivity of FMCs, several analytical models were proposed. It was shown that the best was the opportunity-triggered maintenance policy (OTP). However, this research did not consider cost in developing maintenance models.

To make efficient replacement decisions, sometimes it is important to consider more than one criterion. Castro and Cavalca [17] and Fonseca et al. [18] considered multiple criteria for maintenance decision making, and used genetic algorithms to optimize the decision process. Sachdeva et al. [19] proposed a multiobjective optimization method that selected an optimal preventive maintenance schedule without considering the condition of the equipment. Wang [20] suggested considering both cost and reliability simultaneously in maintenance decision making. Castanier et al. [21] developed a parametric model for inspecting and maintaining a system that was subject to stochastic gradual deterioration. This model has been used to schedule non-periodic inspections and choose among possible maintenance actions. Finally, a decision framework was proposed to choose the best sequence of maintenance action and to schedule future inspections. Grall et al. [22] proposed a model for condition-based inspection/replacement, where the state of the system could be observed through inspection. To assess the performance of different maintenance policies, they developed a cost model. Baxter et al. [23] discussed using the stochastic point process for analysis of reparable units. Their model assumed that, after the repair, the virtual age of the unit was a random variable. Dijoux and Gaudoin [24] proposed a new model called alert-delay (AD) to find the dependence between condition-based preventive maintenance time and corrective maintenance time in terms of a warning of the system and a supplementary time. Statistical analyses of this model, along with the simulation results with a real dataset, were presented to show the effectiveness of this model.

From the above review of the literature, we see that little effort has been made on the analysis of maintenance decision making that uses the complete history of condition information to predict the residual life distribution. To facilitate maintenance decision making, we analyse in detail the long-run average cost model and the long-run average availability model. To minimize the long-run average cost and maximize the long-run average availability, we propose a multiobjective decision frontier that will assist the maintenance managers to deal with trade-offs between objectives. We propose another modified model for replacement decisions, which allows decision makers to obtain at least a minimum level of long-run average availability.

This paper is organized as follows. Section 2 describes a condition- and age-based replacement policy using the SFP-based model developed by Wang [6]. We investigate the properties of hazard rate obtained from the SFP for different combinations of parameters. Section 3 formulates a condition- and age-based replacement model. This model is investigated using a theoretic approach to find the optimal replacement time, T*. Section 4 discusses an availability-based age-replacement model, which is also investigated using a theoretic approach to find the optimal replacement time, T*. Section 5 formulates a multiobjective condition- and age-based replacement model for minimizing long-run average cost, C(T), and maximizing long-run average availability, A(T). Finally, a decision frontier is discussed that deals with trade-offs between the two objectives. Another method is also proposed and explained for replacement decision making when the maintenance manager is required to maintain a minimum level of long-run average availability. Section 6 gives numerical examples for the different models. Section 7 summarizes our conclusions and suggests future research avenues.

sec.title: 2 Replacement Decision Models
sec.p: Age-replacement models can be integrated with residual lifetime distributions conditional on past monitoring history for minimizing the long-run average cost or maximizing the long-run average availability. A residual lifetime distribution can be obtained using the SFP technique proposed by Wang [6]. We use the following two subsections to discuss the age-based replacement policy and the SFP.

sec.title: 2.1 Age-replacement policy
sec.p: The age-based replacement policy preventively replaces equipment when it reaches a predefined age, T, at a cost of Cp, or correctively replaces if it fails before T at a cost of Cf [25]. Generally, preventive replacement cost is less than failure replacement cost (Cp < Cf), and equipment is assumed to return to the ‘as good as new’ state after preventive replacement or failure replacement.

sec.title: 2.2 The SFP
sec.p: We can use the SFP reported by Wang [6] to estimate a residual lifetime distribution, fi(xi|Yi), based on conditions recorded from time zero to time ti. The SFP is used to establish the relationship between all the condition information and the residual lifetime distribution, using a delay time model (DTM) and conditional probability. According to the DTM, the residual delay time at ti is the residual delay time at ti−1minus the interval between ti and ti−1, given that the equipment has survived to ti. We will use the notations given in Appendix 1 throughout this paper.

To obtain the final expression for conditional residual life, a Weibull distribution with scale parameter, α, and shape parameter, β, is used to represent the lifetime distribution at time zero. The distribution of the data on condition is also assumed to follow the Weibull distribution with scale parameter, ρ, and shape parameter, η. It is noted that other distributions can also be used, and the best can be selected by a goodness-of-fit measure. There is assumed to be a negative correlation between the residual lifetime, xi, and the condition information, yi; that is, the higher the condition information, the shorter the residual lifetime. This relationship is incorporated by the expression ρ=1A+B−Cxi.

Therefore, we use this conditional lifetime distribution in this paper to carry out our analysis for condition-based replacement decision.

sec.title: 2.3 Properties of hazard rate
sec.p: In condition-based maintenance, the behaviour of the hazard rate is a key factor in replacement decision making. It is therefore necessary to investigate the properties of the hazard rate, which is obtained from the complete history of condition information and current age. It is difficult to analyse the properties of the above hazard rate function since it has many components and involves an integration operator. For this reason, we analysed the hazard rate function using the bearing data given by Wang [6] (shown in Fig. 1) to empirically prove that what parameter combinations; that is, η and β combinations, cause the hazard rate to increase or strictly increase. The values of the estimated parameters of the hazard rate function are: α = 0.011, β = 1.8729, η = 4.5593, A = 7.0688, B = 27.089, and C = 0.0528. Figure 1 shows the total energy of the vibration data in terms of the root mean square (r.m.s.) values, with respect to the number of operating hours for the six bearings. These r.m.s. values increase for all bearings as they age, once faults have developed. It is important to also note that, as Fig. 1 (which is in the early stage of the bearing life) shows, the r.m.s. values for the vibration data remain flat, but after a certain number of hours of operation, they increase rapidly. These early increases mark the starting point of the defective stage. They also divide the life of a bearing into two stages.

To shed some light on what values for η and β affect the hazard rate, we have divided this analysis into four cases based on different combinations of these parameters. The four cases are: η > 1 and β > 1, η < 1 and β > 1, η > 1 and β < 1, η < 1 and β < 1. It is found that in all cases, f(xi) decreases while g(xi) increases, and it approaches a constant value when xi is very large (shown in Figs 13–16 in Appendix 2). The denominator decreases with xi, and the decreasing rate of the denominator in hi(xi|Yi) dominates the decreasing rate of the f(xi), which is a part of the numerator. Thus, the resultant value for hi(xi|Yi) always increases. From these four cases, it is clear that condition-based hazard rate derived from SFP has an increasing property. It is strictly increasing with increasing slope when η is greater than 1, and increases slowly when η is less than 1 (shown in Fig. 2). As a result, we can conclude that hazard rate increases strictly when η is greater than 1, regardless of whetherβ > 1 or β < 1, in this case.

sec.title: 3 Condition- and Age-Based Replacement Model for Minimizing Cost
sec.p: In the traditional age-based replacement models, the optimum replacement time, T*, is selected to minimize the expected total cost per unit of time. Two types of cost models, namely an infinite-horizon cost model and a one-replacement-cycle cost model, are available in the literature [5, 26–28]. An infinite-horizon cost model is applicable where the maintenance manager wants to carry out the same replacement strategy over a very long period of time. In this paper, we focus on the infinite-horizon cost model. A preliminary model for this purpose has been presented in Lipi et al. [29].

In the infinite-horizon cost model, the renewal-reward theorem is invoked to minimize the long-run average cost per unit of time [1, 30]. According to the renewal–reward theorem, the long-run average cost per unit of time is equal to the expected cost during a life cycle divided by the expected length of the life cycle

We see that for Case 1, the C(T) function decreases until it reaches a minimum point, which is the optimal replacement time. Immediately after this optimal replacement time, the C(T) function increases monotonically. sec.p: If we want to minimize long-run average cost and maximize long-run average availability, we have a multiobjective optimization problem. The following set of objective functions and constraints form the multiobjective optimization problem

To find the solutions to this multiobjective optimization problem, we can construct a decision frontier to assist the maintenance manager in dealing with trade-offs between cost and availability, while making replacement decisions.

On the other hand, sometimes maintenance managers need to minimize long-run average cost while satisfying at least a minimum level of long-run average availability, ξ, which is referred to as the availability threshold. As a result, we have the following modified optimization model

Production managers set a target production quantity required to be produced within a specified time period on the basis of customer requirements. This production target is the main criterion that can be used to choose the threshold for A(T). To meet the requirements for a larger production quantity, the maintenance manager is asked to set a higher threshold value for A(T). This restriction allows the maintenance personnel to make maintenance decisions in such a way that the long-run average availability of the equipment will be at least the threshold value, and the target production level could be achieved within the given time frame.

From the uniqueness of the cost and availability functions observed in theorems 1 and 2, we see that long-run average cost is a convex function, and long-run average availability is a concave function. sec.p: We have used the vibration data for the six bearings reported in section 2.3 to demonstrate the effectiveness of the decision models described in this paper (see Fig. 1).

sec.title: 6.3 Minimizing C(T) and maximizing A(T)
sec.p: To determine the optimal preventive replacement time taking into consideration the two objectives minimization of the long-run average cost, C(T), and maximization of the long-run average availability, A(T), we can analyse the two single objective optimization outcomes shown in Fig. 11, where the preventive replacement time at the 272nd hour is optimal when we aim to maximize A(T), and the preventive replacement time at the 279th hour is optimal when we aim to minimize C(T). As a result, an alternative preventive replacement time earlier than the 272nd hour and later than the 279th hour cannot be optimal when both objectives are considered. Taking this into consideration, we develop the following decision frontier (illustrated in Fig. 12) to help the decision maker deal with trade-offs between these two conflicting objectives. In Fig. 12, the vertical axis corresponds to C(T), and the horizontal axis corresponds to A(T). The numbers plotted represent the preventive replacement times corresponding to the measures of cost and availability. The concept of decision frontier is used when there are multiple objectives in an optimization problem. Usually, the multiple objectives compete with one another. Improving the value of one objective function results in the compromise of the other objective functions. In our problem, the two competing objective functions are to maximize the availability function A(T) and to minimize the cost function C(T). The decision frontier given in Fig. 12 provides the maintenance manager with the optimal options for replacement, depending on the desired trade-off between the optimal values of the two objectives. On this frontier, each point reflects the value of the replacement time and its associated long-run average cost and long-run average availability. The decision maker can easily choose from this frontier the replacement time that best satisfies their preference regarding the conflicting objectives.

In other words, the threshold value (ξ) for A(T) is 0.9815 that is, we want to determine a replacement time that will give us a long-run average availability of at least 0.9815. This threshold value is used in Fig. 11 for graphically determining the replacement time. It gives us a range of replacement times, T∈[264,276], over which the objective function will be optimized. Using equation (19), we see that our optimal replacement time is the 276th hour.

sec.title: 7 Conclusions
sec.p: The models reported in this paper will help maintenance managers select the optimum preventive replacement time for either maximizing long-run average availability or minimizing long-run average cost, or balancing these two objectives, taking into account the complete condition history of the equipment. A detailed analytical investigation has been performed that studies the nature of the long-run average cost model and the long-run average availability model. From the observations made during the course of this investigation, two theorems have been proposed for analysing the properties of the models and calculating the optimum replacement time. To minimize long-run average cost and maximize long-run average availability, a decision frontier has been developed. Finally, numerical examples have been presented for each scenario in order to show the effectiveness of the proposed methods. Results obtained from the multiobjective optimization problem will assist the maintenance decision maker with applying their preferences. In practical applications, maintenance managers often need to make compromises between cost and availability. If they want to minimize cost, they may choose to live with a lower availability. If they want to maximize the availability, they will have to spend more money. The decision frontier provides all options relevant to finding the best trade-off between these two conflicting objectives. This frontier can be generated ahead of time for the use of the maintenance manager. This method could be further investigated by integrating other relevant objectives and various imperfect maintenance policies to see what effects they would have on replacement decisions.
